data_findings.finding: Problem: Pack Christmas tree toys (polygon shapes) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum of (side_length^2 / N) for all N. Lower is better. Target: 68.919154
Pre-optimized solutions (saspav, bucket-of-chump) score ~70.66. Target is 68.92. Gap of 1.74 points. Small N values (1-10) contribute most to score due to side^2/N formula.

bbox3 is a C++ SA optimizer with 14 move types: single-tree moves, swap, bbox pull/push, corner tree focus, fluid dynamics, hinge pivot, density gradient flow, global boundary tension. Uses complex number vector coordination.

Key 2D polygon packing techniques: No-Fit Polygon (NFP) for collision detection, Simulated Annealing, Bottom-Left (BL) algorithm, shelf packing, meta-CSP approaches. NFP is cornerstone for efficient nesting algorithms.

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for 2D polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding:
Two‑dimensional polygon packing asks how to place a set of (often irregular) polygons inside a container – a rectangle, strip, or set of bins – while respecting non‑overlap and possibly allowing rotations, with the goal of minimizing the used area, height, or number of containers.  The problem is NP‑hard and appears in many industries (cutting‑stock, shipbuilding, textile, additive manufacturing) where material utilization is critical ([Frontiers review](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)).  A broad taxonomy distinguishes **strip‑packing**, **bin‑packing**, and **nesting** (irregular‑shape) variants, each of which can be tackled with exact, approximation, or heuristic methods ([Survey 2002](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221702001236); [Survey 2006](https://www.csc.liv.ac.uk/~epa/surveyhtml.html)).

**Exact and mathematically rigorous approaches** model the placement as integer or constraint‑programming problems.  A meta‑CSP

web_research.query: What are the best simulated annealing parameters and cooling schedules for 2D packing optimization?
web_research.finding:
Simulated annealing (SA) solves 2‑D packing by repeatedly perturbing a layout and accepting worse solutions with a probability that depends on a **temperature** \(T\).  The most influential SA settings are the **initial temperature**, the **cooling schedule** that reduces \(T\) over the run, the **length of the Markov chain** (how many neighbour moves are tried at each temperature), and the **stopping rule** (e.g., when the acceptance rate falls below a threshold or a maximum number of temperature updates is reached) ([Springer 2025](https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/BF02283751.pdf); [Springer 2007](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-71618-1_56)).

Empirical work on bin‑packing shows that a **geometric cooling schedule** \(T_{k+1}= \alpha T_k\) with a slow decay ( \(\alpha\) ≈ 0.90–0.99) consistently yields the highest‑quality packings; Kämpke (2025) compared several schedules and identified this “slow‑geometric” scheme as the best for a 100‑item benchmark
